docs.snippet: Q. Is it possible to change the search engine page that comes up automatically in the Search Companion area of Internet Explorer 6? I would like to switch from MSN to Google.    A. MSN Search is Microsoft's default search engine, which pops up whe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to change the search engine page that comes up automatically in the Search Companion area of Internet Explorer 6? I would like to switch from MSN to Google. A. MSN Search is Microsoft's default search engine, which pops up when you type a query into the Search Companion panel on the left side of your screen in Windows XP. If you prefer to use Google or another search engine, you can change the setting. If the Search Companion is not visible, click on the Search button on the Internet Explorer toolbar. Select the Change Preferences option under the box in which you type search terms. Then click on Change Internet Search Behavior on the next screen.

headline.main: Selecting a Search Tool For Your Web Browser

docs.snippet: Vive la Différence      Is a fork male or female? How about a palm tree? A blank CD? A light bulb?    Nouns are assigned a gender in many languages, but not in English. This linguistic peculiarity is the inspiration for www.beautyinchaos.com/sex....
docs.lead_paragraph: Vive la Différence Is a fork male or female? How about a palm tree? A blank CD? A light bulb? Nouns are assigned a gender in many languages, but not in English. This linguistic peculiarity is the inspiration for www.beautyinchaos.com/sex.html, a new site that asks visitors to vote on whether an object is male or female.
docs.abstract: Online Diary column; Web site is collecting votes on whether certain nouns should be gender specific in English; researchers at Carnegie Mellon University create online game to help label millions of unmarked images; Google demonstrates how widespread poor spelling and usage have become; miscellaneous Web sites noted; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: The boom in Internet pop-up advertisement may be about to, well, pop.      The big ads that flash in separate windows above or below Web pages are among the most intrusive, and to many people, the most obnoxious features on the Internet. Not coinc...
docs.lead_paragraph: The boom in Internet pop-up advertisement may be about to, well, pop. The big ads that flash in separate windows above or below Web pages are among the most intrusive, and to many people, the most obnoxious features on the Internet. Not coincidentally, the pop-up format is also among the most effective for advertisers and the most profitable for Web site publishers.

headline.main: As Consumers Revolt, a Rush to Block Pop-Up Online Ads

docs.abstract: Complaints from customers prompt major Internet companies, including EarthLink, AOL, Yahoo and Google, to distribute software that blocks pop-up ads from opening; Microsoft will put pop-up blocking feature in next release of Internet Explorer, dominant Web browser; pop-ups, most obnoxious feature on Internet, are also most effective for advertisers and most profitable for Web site publishers, and advertising executives warn that consumers who block ads are undercutting economic model that provides them with free entertainment and information; photos; graphs (M)

docs.snippet: TIME was -- say, two months ago -- when typing the phrase ''miserable failure'' into the Google search box produced an unexpected result: the White House's official biography of President George W. Bush.     But now the president has a fight on hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: TIME was -- say, two months ago -- when typing the phrase ''miserable failure'' into the Google search box produced an unexpected result: the White House's official biography of President George W. Bush. But now the president has a fight on his hands for the top ranking -- from former President Jimmy Carter, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and the author-filmmaker Michael Moore.
docs.abstract: Article discusses Google bombing, a group sport taking advantage of Web-indexing algorithms used by Google; perpetrators recruit accomplices to link from their Web sites to target site using specific anchor text; Web sites noted; photo (M)

docs.snippet: THE assumption of many providers of high-speed Internet service today is that you are a power user; that is, you don't need any help. You manage your e-mail with a free service like Hotmail or Yahoo, or know how to set up a POP3 account in Outlook...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE assumption of many providers of high-speed Internet service today is that you are a power user; that is, you don't need any help. You manage your e-mail with a free service like Hotmail or Yahoo, or know how to set up a POP3 account in Outlook. You already have software to protect you from hackers, viruses and spyware. You have a working knowledge of Photoshop (or at least Photoshop Elements) and you share pictures with family members at Ofoto. Google is your research hub, you download movie trailers at QuickTime.com, and you may even subscribe to a streaming music service like Rhapsody. You're a Net veteran, and all you require of your service provider is an always-on connection to a fat Internet pipeline.

headline.main: For Those in the Fast Lane, MSN Tries to Smooth the Way

docs.snippet: GOOGLE vanity is getting to be costly.    As Internet users seek to differentiate themselves from people who share their names, some are buying their way to prominence on Google, Yahoo and other search engines. The added exposure comes courtesy of...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE vanity is getting to be costly. As Internet users seek to differentiate themselves from people who share their names, some are buying their way to prominence on Google, Yahoo and other search engines. The added exposure comes courtesy of keyword advertising, in which marketers -- or common folk, for that matter -- bid to have brief advertisements appear atop or beside search results whenever Internet users type in certain words.

headline.main: For a Fee, Wind Up Atop the Search Heap

docs.abstract: Article discusses increased practice of purchasing keyword advertising on Internet search engines to advertise personal names; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Google has cleared one of the last remaining hurdles in its closely watched effort to sell shares to the public, people close to the company said Monday, receiving a clean bill of health in a company-paid audit certifying its compliance with the r...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google has cleared one of the last remaining hurdles in its closely watched effort to sell shares to the public, people close to the company said Monday, receiving a clean bill of health in a company-paid audit certifying its compliance with the requirements of the Sarbanes-Oxley law approved by Congress in 2002 in response to the wave of corporate scandals. The report is a crucial step in Google's carefully staged path toward an initial public offering that is expected to take place this spring. Google's board has been awaiting the report before giving the final go-ahead for the company to file a formal stock registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to several executives involved with the process.

headline.main: Audit Results Move Google A Step Closer To Offering

docs.abstract: Google has cleared of last remaining hurdles in its closely watched effort to sell shares to public, receiving clean bill of health in company-paid audit certifying its compliance with requirements of Sarbanes-Oxley law approved by Congress in 2002 in response to wave of corrupt scandals; report is crucial step in Google's carefully staged path toward initial public offering that is expected to take place this spring (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Your Message Here'' (Jan. 22), on manipulating Web search-engine results to produce political commentary: By giving attention and column inches to a prank that is the work of those with too much time on their hands, this art...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Your Message Here'' (Jan. 22), on manipulating Web search-engine results to produce political commentary: By giving attention and column inches to a prank that is the work of those with too much time on their hands, this article helped validate a squalid phenomenon.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Your Message Here'' (Jan. 22), on engineering Google for political results, is fascinating and frightening. As more and more people realize the possibilities of redirecting Google searches, in particular for commercial gain, th...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Your Message Here'' (Jan. 22), on engineering Google for political results, is fascinating and frightening. As more and more people realize the possibilities of redirecting Google searches, in particular for commercial gain, the program will become less useful. Unless programmers can find a way to defeat the misdirection, the public will eventually lose its most effective tools for surfing the Web. ABRAHAM IRWIN Delray Beach, Fla.
